awd_titl_txt: SCC-PG: Improving Low Income Households' Access to Energy in Washington, D.C.
awd_abstract_narration:
Households at or below the poverty line can owe a significant portion of their income for utility bills; in Washington D.C., this amount is 20% or more before receiving assistance. During heat waves and cold snaps, some residents must forgo expenditures on health, nutrition, or education to pay their air conditioning and heating bills. Delivering innovative technology that utilizes renewable sources to provide affordable, reliable, resilient, and clean power to underserved communities will help reduce the burden on them. This planning grant will develop best practices for engaging residents of urban communities in decisions regarding their energy future while also developing new technologies that address their needs. Taking into account financing and policy innovations to implement the technology can position underserved communities to better take advantage of opportunities in the growing information-based economy. In broader terms, by rethinking the relationship between the built environment and socioeconomic systems, this project seeks to address the inequalities that define the status quo in low-income areas. The main innovation in terms of fundamental research is to develop new methodologies for integrating meaningful community participation, innovative technologies, supportive public policy, and innovative business models to develop and implement affordable energy solutions.

This planning grant aims to develop multidisciplinary methodologies and best practices for engaging residents of underserved urban communities in decisions regarding their energy future, while also developing engineering solutions, specifically sensor-driven micro-grid technologies, that offer such communities a practical option for accessing electric service that is affordable, reliable, resilient, and clean. The project brings together faculty and practitioners from engineering, law, business, public health, and sustainability who will work to develop the necessary new technology, but also have the ability to ensure that city policies facilitate using the technology, that there is financing for it, that it meets community needs, and increases resilience to natural hazards. While the community partners are in Washington DC, this project will identify practices and technologies that are replicable and scalable to other communities across the US.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
This planning grant project worked to enable underserved communities to leverage intelligent energy, communication, and transportation infrastructure to promote improved health outcomes. Working with community members, the project team developed a proposal to design and implement a scalable, transferable model of university-community engagement in technology design and implementation through the use of three types of community navigators – public housing employees, community healthcare workers, and residential council leaders. The project focused on Washington, DC, envisioning a pilot demonstration with communities located east of the Anacostia River which have suffered from underdevelopment for decades.

The intellectual merit of the project entailed efforts to answer the question of how to combine innovations in the electrical grid, healthcare system, and transportation sector in ways that complement each other and make the overall energy transition more just, leveraging a relatively small investment to generate returns in several areas that policy makers usually do not address in a comprehensive manner. In the social sphere, the key questions addressed how to improve health outcomes in underserved communities drawing on improved energy and transportation infrastructure. In the technical sphere, the project sought to use the evolving energy infrastructure as an equity enabler. Specifically, the project allowed the PIs to investigate the resilient and more flexible planning and operation of microgrids against extreme events. In particular, the PIs researched and proposed new and uncertainty-aware mechanisms to (1) design and plan power distribution systems composed of microgrids that are more flexible, reliable, and resilient to extreme events, (2) co-optimize the operation and deployment of a variety of energy resources within smart microgrids (e.g., micro wind turbines and renewable energy resources, mobile power sources, network topology, and flexible reconfigurability, electric vehicles, etc.) in facilitating a fast and effective response and recovery before, during, and following disasters, and (3) co-optimize and coordinate the interdependent operation of power distribution systems and microgrids with the water distribution network, thus enabling a smart, efficient, and reliable water-energy nexus of the future.    

In terms of broader impacts, the proposal sought to implement energy transformations that would expand access to electrification infrastructure, particularly electric vehicle charging facilities, in ways that make it possible for healthcare providers to deliver preventative and primary services directly to communities where access to such services is often difficult. The navigator model helps to extend methodologies that facilitate community input into technology development processes, ensuring the innovations meet community needs. The technical innovations sought to leverage the policy preferences articulated by the city government, Public Service Commission, local utility, local hospitals, and transportation advocates. The project proposal identified ways to overcome legal and regulatory barriers that will be needed to reform the operations of the local electrical grid and implement the related innovations with a clear-eyed understanding of the interests of the different players in the system. Finally, the planning grant helped to extend and deepen the capacity of George Washington University to work collaboratively with neighboring communities in Washington, DC.

 


Last Modified: 12/01/2022
Modified by: Robert Orttung
